name: Ext.parse.Tokenizer
doc:
This class is used to parse a string into a series of tokens. The syntax of the string is JavaScript-like. This class is useful for creating higher-level parsers to allow them to assemble tokens into a meaningful language (such as bind properties).

The following set of punctuation characters are supported:

 + - * / ! , : [ ] { } ( )

This class does not currently separate the dot operator but instead includes it in a single "ident" token. Whitespace between tokens is skipped.

Tokens are parsed on-demand when next or peek are called. As much as possible, the returned tokens are reused (e.g., to represent tokens like ":" the same object is always returned). For tokens that contain values, a new object must be created to return the value. Even so, the is property that describes the data is a reused object in all cases.

 var tokenizer;  // see below for getting instance

 for (;;) {
     if (!(token = tokenizer.next())) {
         // When null is returned, there are no more tokens

         break;
     }

     var is = token.is;  // the token's classification object

     if (is.error) {
         // Once an error is encountered, it will always be returned by
         // peek or next. The error is cleared by calling reset().

         console.log('Syntax error', token.message);
         break;
     }

     if (is.ident) {
         // an identifier...
         // use token.value to access the name or dot-path

         var t = tokenizer.peek();  // don't consume next token (yet)

         if (t && t.is.parenOpen) {
             tokenizer.next();  // we'll take this one

             parseThingsInParens();

             t = tokenizer.next();

             mustBeCloseParen(t);
         }
     }
     else if (is.literal) {
         // a literal value (null, true/false, string, number)
         // use token.value to access the value
     }
     else if (is.at) {
         // @
     }
 }

For details on the returned token see the peek method.

There is a pool of flyweight instances to reduce memory allocation.

 var tokenizer = Ext.parse.Tokenizer.fly('some.thing:foo()');

 // use tokenizer (see above)

 tokenizer.release();  // returns the fly to the flyweigt pool

The release method returns the flyweight to the pool for later reuse. Failure to call release will leave the flyweight empty which simply forces the fly method to always create new instances on each call.

A tokenizer can also be reused by calling its reset method and giving it new text to tokenize.

 this.tokenizer = new Ext.parse.Tokenizer();

 // Later...

 this.tokenizer.reset('some.thing:foo()');

 // use tokenizer (see above)

 this.tokenizer.reset();

The final call to reset is optional but will avoid holding large text strings or parsed results that rae no longer needed.

members.name: keywords
members.doc: A map of keywords that should be mapped to other token types. By default the null, true and false keywords are mapped to their respective literal value tokens.
members.short_doc: A map of keywords that should be mapped to other token types. ...

members.name: operators
members.doc: A map of operators and their names. The keys are the operator text and the name (the values) are placed in the token's is object as true.
members.short_doc: A map of operators and their names. ...

members.name: $className
$configPrefixed
members.doc: The value true causes config values to be stored on instances using a property name prefixed with an underscore ("_") character. A value of false stores config values as properties using their exact name (no prefix).
members.short_doc:
The value true causes config values to be stored on instances using a
property name prefixed with an underscore ("_")...

members.name: $configStrict
members.doc: The value true instructs the initConfig method to only honor values for properties declared in the config block of a class. When false, properties that are not declared in a config block will be placed on the instance.
members.short_doc:
The value true instructs the initConfig method to only honor values for
properties declared in the config block of a ...

members.name: clearPropertiesOnDestroy
members.doc: Setting this property to false will prevent nulling object references on a Class instance after destruction. Setting this to "async" will delay the clearing for approx 50ms.
members.short_doc:
Setting this property to false will prevent nulling object references
on a Class instance after destruction. ...

members.name: clearPrototypeOnDestroy
members.doc:
Setting this property to true will result in setting the object's prototype to null after the destruction sequence is fully completed. After that, most attempts at calling methods on the object instance will result in "method not defined" exception. This can be very helpful with tracking down otherwise hard to find bugs like runaway Ajax requests, timed functions not cleared on destruction, etc.

Note that this option can only work in browsers that support Object.setPrototypeOf method, and is only available in debugging mode.
members.short_doc:
Setting this property to true will result in setting the object's
prototype to null after the destruction sequence is...

members.name: destroyed
members.doc: This property is set to true after the destroy method is called.
members.short_doc: This property is set to true after the destroy method is called. ...

members.name: end
members.doc: The index one beyond the last character of the input text. This defaults to the text.length.
members.short_doc: The index one beyond the last character of the input text. ...

members.name: error
members.doc: This property is set to an Error instance if the parser encounters a syntax error.

members.name: head
members.doc: The current token at the head of the token stream. This will be undefined if the next token must be parsed from text. It is null if there are no more tokens.
members.short_doc: The current token at the head of the token stream. ...

members.name: index
members.doc: This property is set to the character index of the current token. This value can be captured immediately after calling the peek or next method to know the index of the returned token. This value is not included in the returned token to allow those tokens that could otherwise be immutable to be reused.
members.short_doc: This property is set to the character index of the current token. ...

members.name: isConfiguring
members.doc: This property is set to true during the call to initConfig.
members.short_doc: This property is set to true during the call to initConfig. ...

members.name: isFirstInstance
members.doc: This property is set to true if this instance is the first of its class.
members.short_doc: This property is set to true if this instance is the first of its class. ...

members.name: isInstance
members.doc: This value is true and is used to identify plain objects from instances of a defined class.
members.short_doc:
This value is true and is used to identify plain objects from instances of
a defined class. ...

pos
members.doc: The current character position in the text from which the next token will be parsed.

The current character position in the text from which the next token will

members.name: privates
self
members.doc:
Get the reference to the current class from which this object was instantiated. Unlike statics, this.self is scope-dependent and it's meant to be used for dynamic inheritance. See statics for a detailed comparison

Ext.define('My.Cat', {
    statics: {
        speciesName: 'Cat' // My.Cat.speciesName = 'Cat'
    },

    constructor: function() {
        alert(this.self.speciesName); // dependent on 'this'
    },

    clone: function() {
        return new this.self();
    }
});


Ext.define('My.SnowLeopard', {
    extend: 'My.Cat',
    statics: {
        speciesName: 'Snow Leopard'         // My.SnowLeopard.speciesName = 'Snow Leopard'
    }
});

var cat = new My.Cat();                     // alerts 'Cat'
var snowLeopard = new My.SnowLeopard();     // alerts 'Snow Leopard'

var clone = snowLeopard.clone();
alert(Ext.getClassName(clone));             // alerts 'My.SnowLeopard'
members.short_doc: Get the reference to the current class from which this object was instantiated. ...

members.name: text
members.doc: The text to be tokenized.

members.name: callOverridden
members.doc:
Call the original method that was previously overridden with override

Ext.define('My.Cat', {
    constructor: function() {
        alert("I'm a cat!");
    }
});

My.Cat.override({
    constructor: function() {
        alert("I'm going to be a cat!");

        this.callOverridden();

        alert("Meeeeoooowwww");
    }
});

var kitty = new My.Cat(); // alerts "I'm going to be a cat!"
                          // alerts "I'm a cat!"
                          // alerts "Meeeeoooowwww"

params.name: args
params.doc: The arguments, either an array or the arguments object from the current method, for example: this.callOverridden(arguments)

return.name: return
return.doc: Returns the result of calling the overridden method

members.name: callParent
members.doc:
Call the "parent" method of the current method. That is the method previously overridden by derivation or by an override (see Ext.define).

 Ext.define('My.Base', {
     constructor: function (x) {
         this.x = x;
     },

     statics: {
         method: function (x) {
             return x;
         }
     }
 });

 Ext.define('My.Derived', {
     extend: 'My.Base',

     constructor: function () {
         this.callParent([21]);
     }
 });

 var obj = new My.Derived();

 alert(obj.x);  // alerts 21

This can be used with an override as follows:

 Ext.define('My.DerivedOverride', {
     override: 'My.Derived',

     constructor: function (x) {
         this.callParent([x*2]); // calls original My.Derived constructor
     }
 });

 var obj = new My.Derived();

 alert(obj.x);  // now alerts 42

This also works with static and private methods.

 Ext.define('My.Derived2', {
     extend: 'My.Base',

     // privates: {
     statics: {
         method: function (x) {
             return this.callParent([x*2]); // calls My.Base.method
         }
     }
 });

 alert(My.Base.method(10));     // alerts 10
 alert(My.Derived2.method(10)); // alerts 20

Lastly, it also works with overridden static methods.

 Ext.define('My.Derived2Override', {
     override: 'My.Derived2',

     // privates: {
     statics: {
         method: function (x) {
             return this.callParent([x*2]); // calls My.Derived2.method
         }
     }
 });

 alert(My.Derived2.method(10); // now alerts 40

To override a method and replace it and also call the superclass method, use callSuper. This is often done to patch a method to fix a bug.

params.name: args
params.doc: The arguments, either an array or the arguments object from the current method, for example: this.callParent(arguments)

return.name: return
return.doc: Returns the result of calling the parent method

members.short_doc: Call the "parent" method of the current method. ...

members.name: callSuper
members.doc:
This method is used by an override to call the superclass method but bypass any overridden method. This is often done to "patch" a method that contains a bug but for whatever reason cannot be fixed directly.

Consider:

 Ext.define('Ext.some.Class', {
     method: function () {
         console.log('Good');
     }
 });

 Ext.define('Ext.some.DerivedClass', {
     extend: 'Ext.some.Class',

     method: function () {
         console.log('Bad');

         // ... logic but with a bug ...

         this.callParent();
     }
 });

To patch the bug in Ext.some.DerivedClass.method, the typical solution is to create an override:

 Ext.define('App.patches.DerivedClass', {
     override: 'Ext.some.DerivedClass',

     method: function () {
         console.log('Fixed');

         // ... logic but with bug fixed ...

         this.callSuper();
     }
 });

The patch method cannot use callParent to call the superclass method since that would call the overridden method containing the bug. In other words, the above patch would only produce "Fixed" then "Good" in the console log, whereas, using callParent would produce "Fixed" then "Bad" then "Good".

params.name: args
params.doc: The arguments, either an array or the arguments object from the current method, for example: this.callSuper(arguments)

return.name: return
return.doc: Returns the result of calling the superclass method

members.short_doc:
This method is used by an override to call the superclass method but
bypass any overridden method. ...

members.name: destroy
members.doc:
This method is called to cleanup an object and its resources. After calling this method, the object should not be used any further in any way, including access to its methods and properties.

To prevent potential memory leaks, all object references will be nulled at the end of destruction sequence, unless clearPropertiesOnDestroy is set to false.
members.short_doc: This method is called to cleanup an object and its resources. ...

members.name: destroyMembers
members.doc:
Destroys member properties by name.

If a property name is the name of a config, the getter is not invoked, so if the config has not been initialized, nothing will be done.

The property will be destroyed, and the corrected name (if the property is a config and config names are prefixed) will set to null in this object's dictionary.

params.name: args
params.doc: One or more names of the properties to destroy and remove from the object.

members.short_doc: Destroys member properties by name. ...

members.name: getConfig
members.doc: Returns a specified config property value. If the name parameter is not passed, all current configuration options will be returned as key value pairs.

params.name: name
params.doc: The name of the config property to get.

params.name: peek
params.doc: true to peek at the raw value without calling the getter.

params.name: ifInitialized
params.doc: true to only return the initialized property value, not the raw config value, and not to trigger initialization. Returns undefined if the property has not yet been initialized.

members.short_doc: Returns a specified config property value. ...

members.name: getCurrentConfig
getInitialConfig
members.doc:
Returns the initial configuration passed to the constructor when instantiating this class.

Given this example Ext.button.Button definition and instance:

Ext.define('MyApp.view.Button', {
    extend: 'Ext.button.Button',
    xtype: 'mybutton',

    scale: 'large',
    enableToggle: true
});

var btn = Ext.create({
    xtype: 'mybutton',
    renderTo: Ext.getBody(),
    text: 'Test Button'
});

Calling btn.getInitialConfig() would return an object including the config options passed to the create method:

xtype: 'mybutton',
renderTo: // The document body itself
text: 'Test Button'

Calling btn.getInitialConfig('text')returns 'Test Button'.

params.name: name
params.doc: Name of the config option to return.

return.name: return
return.doc: The full config object or a single config value when name parameter specified.

members.short_doc:
Returns the initial configuration passed to the constructor when
instantiating this class. ...

members.doc: Returns the value of keywords.
members.short_doc: Returns the value of keywords. ...

members.name: getOperators
members.doc: Returns the value of operators.
members.short_doc: Returns the value of operators. ...

members.name: hasConfig
initConfig
members.doc:
Initialize configuration for this class. a typical example:

Ext.define('My.awesome.Class', {
    // The default config
    config: {
        name: 'Awesome',
        isAwesome: true
    },

    constructor: function(config) {
        this.initConfig(config);
    }
});

var awesome = new My.awesome.Class({
    name: 'Super Awesome'
});

alert(awesome.getName()); // 'Super Awesome'
members.short_doc: Initialize configuration for this class. ...

members.name: link
members.doc: Adds a "destroyable" object to an internal list of objects that will be destroyed when this instance is destroyed (via method!destroy).
members.short_doc:
Adds a "destroyable" object to an internal list of objects that will be destroyed
when this instance is destroyed (vi...

members.name: next
members.doc:
Advance the token stream and return the next token. See peek for a description of the returned token.

After calling this method, the next call to it or peek will not return the same token but instead the token that follows the one returned.

return.name: return
return.doc: The next token in the stream (now consumed).

members.short_doc: Advance the token stream and return the next token. ...

members.name: parse
members.doc: Parses the current token that starts with the provided character c and located at the current pos in the text.
members.short_doc:
Parses the current token that starts with the provided character c and
located at the current pos in the text. ...

members.name: parseIdent
members.doc: Parses the next identifier token.
members.short_doc: Parses the next identifier token. ...

members.name: parseNumber
members.doc: Parses the next number literal token.
members.short_doc: Parses the next number literal token. ...

members.name: parseString
members.doc: Parses the next string literal token.
members.short_doc: Parses the next string literal token. ...

members.name: peek
members.doc:
Peeks at the next token stream and returns it. The token remains as the next token and will be returned again by the next call to this method or next.

At the end of the token stream, the token returned will be null.

If a syntax error is encountered, the returned token will be an Error object. It has the standard message property and also additional properties to make it more like a standard token: error: true, type: 'error' and at (the index in the string where the syntax error started.

return.name: return
return.doc: The next token in the stream (not yet consumed).

properties.name: type
properties.doc: The type of the token. This will be one of the following values: ident, literal and error or the text of a operator (i.e., "@", "!", ",", ":", "[", "]", "{", "}", "(" or ")").

properties.name: is
properties.doc: An object containing boolean properties based on type.

properties.name: literal
properties.doc: True if the token is a literal value.

properties.name: boolean
properties.doc: True if the token is a literal boolean value.

properties.name: error
properties.doc: True if the token is an error.

properties.name: ident
properties.doc: True if the token is an identifier.

properties.name: nil
properties.doc: True if the token is the null keyword.

properties.name: number
properties.doc: True if the token is a number literal.

properties.name: string
properties.doc: True if the token is a string literal.

properties.name: operator
properties.doc: True if the token is a operator (i.e., "@!,:[]{}()"). operators will also have one of these boolean proprieties, in the respective order: at, bang, comma, colon, arrayOpen, arrayClose, curlyOpen, curlyClose, parentOpen and parenClose).

members.short_doc: Peeks at the next token stream and returns it. ...

members.name: release
members.doc: Returns this flyweight instance to the flyweight pool for reuse.
members.short_doc: Returns this flyweight instance to the flyweight pool for reuse. ...

members.name: reset
members.doc: Resets the tokenizer for a new string at a given offset (defaults to 0).

params.name: pos
params.doc: The character position at which to start.

params.name: end
params.doc: The index of the first character beyond the token range.

members.short_doc: Resets the tokenizer for a new string at a given offset (defaults to 0). ...

members.name: setConfig
members.doc: Sets a single/multiple configuration options.

params.name: name
params.doc: The name of the property to set, or a set of key value pairs to set.
params.html_type: String/Object

params.name: value
params.doc: The value to set for the name parameter.

members.short_doc: Sets a single/multiple configuration options. ...

members.name: setKeywords
members.doc: Sets the value of keywords.
members.short_doc: Sets the value of keywords. ...

members.name: setOperators
members.doc: Sets the value of operators.
members.short_doc: Sets the value of operators. ...

members.name: statics
members.doc:
Get the reference to the class from which this object was instantiated. Note that unlike self, this.statics() is scope-independent and it always returns the class from which it was called, regardless of what this points to during run-time

Ext.define('My.Cat', {
    statics: {
        totalCreated: 0,
        speciesName: 'Cat' // My.Cat.speciesName = 'Cat'
    },

    constructor: function() {
        var statics = this.statics();

        alert(statics.speciesName);     // always equals to 'Cat' no matter what 'this' refers to
                                        // equivalent to: My.Cat.speciesName

        alert(this.self.speciesName);   // dependent on 'this'

        statics.totalCreated++;
    },

    clone: function() {
        var cloned = new this.self();   // dependent on 'this'

        cloned.groupName = this.statics().speciesName;   // equivalent to: My.Cat.speciesName

        return cloned;
    }
});


Ext.define('My.SnowLeopard', {
    extend: 'My.Cat',

    statics: {
        speciesName: 'Snow Leopard'     // My.SnowLeopard.speciesName = 'Snow Leopard'
    },

    constructor: function() {
        this.callParent();
    }
});

var cat = new My.Cat();                 // alerts 'Cat', then alerts 'Cat'

var snowLeopard = new My.SnowLeopard(); // alerts 'Cat', then alerts 'Snow Leopard'

var clone = snowLeopard.clone();
alert(Ext.getClassName(clone));         // alerts 'My.SnowLeopard'
alert(clone.groupName);                 // alerts 'Cat'

alert(My.Cat.totalCreated);             // alerts 3
members.short_doc: Get the reference to the class from which this object was instantiated. ...

members.name: syntaxError
members.doc: This method is called when a syntax error is encountered. It updates error and returns the error token.
members.short_doc: This method is called when a syntax error is encountered. ...

members.doc: Destroys a given set of linked objects. This is only needed if the linked object is being destroyed before this instance.

params.name: names
params.doc: The names of the linked objects to destroy.

members.short_doc: Destroys a given set of linked objects. ...

members.doc: Adds new config properties to this class. This is called for classes when they are declared, then for any mixins that class may define and finally for any overrides defined that target the class.

params.name: mixinClass
params.doc: The mixin class if the configs are from a mixin.

members.name: addInheritableStatics
addMember
addMembers
members.doc:
Add methods / properties to the prototype of this class.

Ext.define('My.awesome.Cat', {
    constructor: function() {
        ...
    }
});

 My.awesome.Cat.addMembers({
     meow: function() {
        alert('Meowww...');
     }
 });

 var kitty = new My.awesome.Cat();
 kitty.meow();

params.name: members
params.doc: The members to add to this class.

params.name: privacy
params.doc: Pass true if the members are private. This only has meaning in debug mode and only for methods.

members.short_doc: Add methods / properties to the prototype of this class. ...

members.name: addStatics
members.doc:
Add / override static properties of this class.

Ext.define('My.cool.Class', {
    ...
});

My.cool.Class.addStatics({
    someProperty: 'someValue',      // My.cool.Class.someProperty = 'someValue'
    method1: function() { ... },    // My.cool.Class.method1 = function() { ... };
    method2: function() { ... }     // My.cool.Class.method2 = function() { ... };
});
members.short_doc: Add / override static properties of this class. ...

members.name: borrow
members.doc:
Borrow another class' members to the prototype of this class.

Ext.define('Bank', {
    money: '$$$',
    printMoney: function() {
        alert('$$$$$$$');
    }
});

Ext.define('Thief', {
    ...
});

Thief.borrow(Bank, ['money', 'printMoney']);

var steve = new Thief();

alert(steve.money); // alerts '$$$'
steve.printMoney(); // alerts '$$$$$$$'

params.name: members
params.doc: The names of the members to borrow
params.html_type: Array/String

members.short_doc: Borrow another class' members to the prototype of this class. ...

members.name: callParent
callSuper
create
members.doc:
Create a new instance of this Class.

Ext.define('My.cool.Class', {
    ...
});

My.cool.Class.create({
    someConfig: true
});

All parameters are passed to the constructor of the class.
members.short_doc: Create a new instance of this Class. ...

members.name: createAlias
members.doc:
Create aliases for existing prototype methods. Example:

Ext.define('My.cool.Class', {
    method1: function() { ... },
    method2: function() { ... }
});

var test = new My.cool.Class();

My.cool.Class.createAlias({
    method3: 'method1',
    method4: 'method2'
});

test.method3(); // test.method1()

My.cool.Class.createAlias('method5', 'method3');

test.method5(); // test.method3() -> test.method1()

params.name: alias
params.doc: The new method name, or an object to set multiple aliases. See flexSetter
params.html_type: String/Object

params.name: origin
params.html_type: String/Object

members.short_doc: Create aliases for existing prototype methods. ...

members.name: extend
fly
members.doc:
Returns a flyweight instance. These instances should be returned when no longer needed by calling release.

Additional arguments passed to this method will be passed on to the reset method.
members.short_doc: Returns a flyweight instance. ...

members.name: getConfigurator
members.doc: Returns the Ext.Configurator for this class.
members.short_doc: Returns the Ext.Configurator for this class. ...

members.name: getName
members.doc:
Get the current class' name in string format.

Ext.define('My.cool.Class', {
    constructor: function() {
        alert(this.self.getName()); // alerts 'My.cool.Class'
    }
});

My.cool.Class.getName(); // 'My.cool.Class'
members.short_doc: Get the current class' name in string format. ...

members.name: mixin
members.doc: Used internally by the mixins pre-processor
members.short_doc: Used internally by the mixins pre-processor ...

members.name: onExtended
override
members.doc:
Override members of this class. Overridden methods can be invoked via method!callParent.

Ext.define('My.Cat', {
    constructor: function() {
        alert("I'm a cat!");
    }
});

My.Cat.override({
    constructor: function() {
        alert("I'm going to be a cat!");

        this.callParent(arguments);

        alert("Meeeeoooowwww");
    }
});

var kitty = new My.Cat(); // alerts "I'm going to be a cat!"
                          // alerts "I'm a cat!"
                          // alerts "Meeeeoooowwww"

Direct use of this method should be rare. Use Ext.define instead:

Ext.define('My.CatOverride', {
    override: 'My.Cat',
    constructor: function() {
        alert("I'm going to be a cat!");

        this.callParent(arguments);

        alert("Meeeeoooowwww");
    }
});

The above accomplishes the same result but can be managed by the Ext.Loader which can properly order the override and its target class and the build process can determine whether the override is needed based on the required state of the target class (My.Cat).

params.name: members
params.doc: The properties to add to this class. This should be specified as an object literal containing one or more properties.

members.short_doc: Override members of this class. ...

members.name: triggerExtended

short_doc: This class is used to parse a string into a series of tokens. ...
